value.title: The best robot vacuums of CES 2022
value.excerpt: Several new floor cleaning robots were revealed at CES 2022. Find out what's new on the botvac scene, and what new technology they're armed with.

value.title: B'luru-based AI and computer vision startup Avataar raises $45 mn
value.excerpt: Bengaluru and San Francisco-based AI and computer vision startup Avataar has raised $45 million in Series B funding led by Tiger Global. Existing investor Sequoia Capital India also participated in the round.

value.title: Telangana’s facial recognition technology comes under scanner
value.excerpt: A division bench of the state high court issued a notice to the state government and the Hyderabad city police commissioner, seeking an explanation over the propriety of the usage of technology and whether it infringes on one’s privacy while being in public places.

value.title: Qualcomm and Microsoft collaborate on custom chips for AR glasses

value.title: Anker shows off the tiniest 100W charger we’ve ever seen and more at CES 2022
value.excerpt: Anker just announced the 736 Nano II Charger at CES 2022, along with a bunch of other products spanning the projector, webcam, and smart home categories.

value.title: LiLz uses computer vision to read gauges and dials where humans prefer not to tread
value.excerpt: No one wants to be the maintenance worker who has to hike through half a mile of damp hallways just to check the pressure gauge on a valve somewhere. LiLz makes it possible to keep an eye on such inconvenient physical interfaces remotely with a clever and practical application of machine learning.

value.title: Future of Work: Computer vision and machine learning may soon bolster restaurant jobs
value.excerpt: Chipotle CEO Brian Niccol expects the restaurant industry to adopt more emerging technologies to deal with challenges like supply chain snags, worker turnover and inefficiency.

value.title: LG builds tech to start cars using facial recognition
value.excerpt: The technology will enable users to start their vehicles as well as make adjustments to control the vehicles through facial expressions and hand gestures.

value.title: Identity verification using Amazon Rekognition
value.excerpt: In-person user identity verification is slow to scale, costly, and high friction for users. Machine learning (ML) powered facial recognition technology can enable online user identity verification. value.title: Telangana: Plea against use of facial recognition technology
value.excerpt: Hyderabad: The Division Bench headed by Chief Justice Satish Chandra Sharma and Justice Abhinand Kumar Shavili on Monday issued notices to Principal Secretary, Municipal Administration & Urban Affairs and the Hyderabad city police commissioner directing them to respond to the notices on implementation of facial recognition technology in Telangana State within six months.

value.title: How AR And Computer Vision Lead To Smart Policing
value.excerpt: AR and computer vision play their part in smart city policing by automating routine yet critical tasks performed by law enforcement personnel.

value.title: Unlock your Windows 11 laptop using your face with Windows Hello
value.excerpt: It isn't exclusive to the iPhone. You can log in to your Windows 10 or Windows 11 laptop just by looking at the webcam.

value.title: How a startup uses AI to put worker safety first
value.excerpt: Everguard combines AI, computer vision, and sensor fusion to prioritize worker safety and reduce the risk of injuries and accidents.

value.title: Report: Computer vision teams worldwide say projects are delayed by insufficient data

value.title: These Ecovacs robot vacuums are 45% off until midnight
value.excerpt: Amazon has what may very well be the final robot vacuum sale of 2021. The online retailer has solid deals on three Ecovacs robot vacuums. These deals won’t arrive before Christmas, but they should get there before the New Year.

value.title: DeWitt Township police will have access to facial recognition software starting in January
value.excerpt: The DeWitt Township Police Department signed an agreement with the Michigan State Police to use their SNAP facial recognition software, which is meant to help officers identify suspects and crime victims while in the field.

value.title: How Leaders Can Use Facial Recognition Technology As A Force For Good
value.excerpt: Facial recognition, when used within moral codes of conduct and an ethical framework, can be very beneficial, and it could be key to streamlined experiences, secure processes and a safer society.

value.title: Face Recognition Is Being Banned—but It’s Still Everywhere
value.excerpt: Two dozen cities and states prohibit use of the tech. But it’s on phones and is increasingly used in airports and in banks.

value.title: Campuses, Law Enforcement Reckon with Facial Recognition Bans
value.excerpt: Implementing facial recognition is becoming more cumbersome as an increasing number of cities and states restrict the use of this technology.
